rev.comment: snip uncited and non-notable section (if it can be rephrased, please cite and put into the [[History of Google]] article, but I digress)

Line 154: Line 154:
In 2004, Google formed a non-profit philanthropic wing, [[Google.org]], with a start-up fund of US$1 billion.<ref name="philanthropy">"[http://www.google.org/about.html About the Foundation]." ''[[Google.org]].'' Retrieved on [[October 11]], [[2007]].</ref> The express mission of the organization is to create awareness about [[climate change]], global public health, and [[global poverty]]. One of its first projects is to develop a viable [[plug-in hybrid]] [[electric vehicle]] that can attain 100 [[fuel economy in automobiles|mpg]]. The current director is Dr. [[Larry Brilliant]].<ref>Hafner, Katie. "[http://www.nytimes.com/2006/09/14/technology/14google.html Philanthropy Googleâs Way: Not the Usual]." ''[[The New York Times]].'' [[September 14]], [[2006]]. Retrieved on [[October 11]], [[2007]].</ref>
In 2004, Google formed a non-profit philanthropic wing, [[Google.org]], with a start-up fund of US$1 billion.<ref name="philanthropy">"[http://www.google.org/about.html About the Foundation]." ''[[Google.org]].'' Retrieved on [[October 11]], [[2007]].</ref> The express mission of the organization is to create awareness about [[climate change]], global public health, and [[global poverty]]. One of its first projects is to develop a viable [[plug-in hybrid]] [[electric vehicle]] that can attain 100 [[fuel economy in automobiles|mpg]]. The current director is Dr. [[Larry Brilliant]].<ref>Hafner, Katie. "[http://www.nytimes.com/2006/09/14/technology/14google.html Philanthropy Googleâs Way: Not the Usual]." ''[[The New York Times]].'' [[September 14]], [[2006]]. Retrieved on [[October 11]], [[2007]].</ref>
â
==Awards & Prizes==
  â
===Google Lunar X Prize===
  â
Google, in conjunction with the [[X Prize Foundation]], have offered a prize of $20 million and $5 million to the first and second organisations to successfully fund and carry out a mission to place a craft on the moon (additionally, this craft should roam for a further minimum of 50 metres, transmitting a specified set of data, including images, back to Earth). A further $5 million will be distributed amongst the other contestants.
  â
Google co-founder Sergey Brin came up with the idea for the contest after chatting with X Prize Foundation Chief Executive Peter Diamandis and PayPal founder Elon Musk. "It occurred to me that [Google] should be doing new kinds of things in ambitious and unexpected ways," Brin said in a statement to the Press.
